content: Good for tracking pain but disappointed there's no option to change the model to a woman. It's irritating to open the app to record my pain and be met with a figure that lacks the appropriate body parts. I'm surprised by this oversight, especially because the app was made by a doctor. Over all, not bad if you need to keep visual reminders for reference. The addition of sideviews would be helpful. The UI could also use some refining; my older parents would probably have trouble using this app.
replyContent: It‚Äôs not an oversight to have one body style depicted. Most pain clinics use a generalized unisex body map and that is the approach we took ‚Äî not ideal, but fairly standard. Nevertheless, your point is appreciated ‚Äî we do have plans to introduce 3 body styles to include the current style, female, male. Pls email us your suggested UI refinements.

content: I bought this app thinking it would help me track my chronic pain but having to restart my drawings all the time because they don't save makes me waste a lot of time. App would have potential. I like that you can draw on the front and back of the body. But having to spend so much time on the app redoing what I had already done just doesn't do it for me.
replyContent: SAVE: When u finish drawing, u must tap "Done" to save it. COPY/EDIT: If u want to replicate a saved drawing, tap the "Copy/Edit" feature. 4-HELP: Tap the info ‚Äúi‚Äù icon on top-left of Entries/Chart screen, then tap "General Help". Scroll down to ‚ÄúViewing, Copying, Deleting, or Adding to the Contents of a Diary Entry‚Äù or for any other help u need.

content: Amazing app!
Fantastic
replyContent: Thank you for your positive comment. It really helps keep us going and working to improve our product. If you have any questions or suggestions, you could write us at: support@nanolume.com. Thanks!

content: Where is the female body choice? That is not "androgynous", it's male without the dangly bits. Add a female (or actual androgynous body like other pain apps) option for a higher rating. Also, can I setup a notification to remind me to enter data every day?
replyContent: Thank you for your comments about the image we currently use. Would you be willing to give us some thoughts on adjustments we can make? If you are willing to do so, could you please contact us: administration@nanolume.com.

content: Good features for drawing pain on diagram. Deducted star: Would like to see the title of a pain type next to the icons, rather than having to remember what each square represents. Would like to see a summary mode with both front/back entry side by side (with legend) and notes included at bottom. Right now to summarize properly requires 3 screenshots--front, back, and notes. Edit: excellent update. Added the above feature. Very good. Bit buried, so may be something you want to make more obvious.
replyContent: TITLES. If you touch a symbol, it‚Äôs title appears in the right-lower corner of the screen next to the corresponding intensity & coverage area.  SUMMARY. We do have a summary mode that creates all that you are looking for. Access ‚ÄúGeneral Help‚Äù and review ‚ÄúSharing Your Data as a PDF file.‚Äù Pls email us for more details or help: support@nanolume.com.

content: Great app to visualize pain and track progress of treatment while getting patients involved in their care

This has changed my life. No more keeping a messy notebook and trying to describe my pain everyday in an effort to just make doctors understand so they'll help me (which has been failing for the past 3 years since this started). No more having to remember the exact time of the pain when I get home (this keeps track of the time I log the pain, and my phone is always with me). Seeing the pain visually is so much more effective, and having a chart to show a summary is just the icing on the cake.
The app crashed all the time whenever I want to make a pdf file.
replyContent: We are sorry you are seeing crashes. We‚Äôve reached out to you several times, and want to help you, but we need you to respond to us. Google confirms your device is a Samsung S6 running Android 7.0 software. We have tested our app and the PDF feature on an S6 running 7.0 software, but we do not see any crashes. Pls contact us: support@nanolume.com.

content: This app is amazing,well worth the money! Its designed for those of us affected by crps. It not only makes it easy for you to see n compare your good n bad days but a great way to break down your specific symptoms and problems to your specialist. I recommend this to not just crps patients but anyone that deals with chronic pain. Thankful to the person that developed this!üôÇ‚ù§
replyContent: Thank you for your user review.  It was awesome and much appreciated!

content: It's pretty good in that it lets you draw specifically where the pain is. I would like it if they would also incorporate things like medications taken and therapies used during the day as well. Even incorporate activities like walking/pt/ot etc. This would be very handy to have all in one spot instead of me using 3 different apps to have all the information handy for my doctors.
replyContent: All of the info you wish to include can be attached to each entry by pressing the ‚ÄúNotes‚Äù icon (upper-left side of each entry). A note icon appears next to the date/time of each entry you attach a note to. The app also allows you to email your pictures+notes. Contact us at administration@nanolume.com w/questions. Thank you for downloading our app.

content: Phenomenally put together! Could work well for the patients in our clinic!!!!
This app is phenomenal. I have worked at a pain clinic for 6 years and this app is game changing! Great job!

Superb - just one slight issue - it's not possible to add pain to the body map (for an entry) once it's saved :-( notes, however, can be retro added. Developer responded with a workaround: basically make a copy (makes a new entry with copied pain) but edit the date time to overwrite the original entry. Works, but I think direct retro edit/update would be preferable.
replyContent: Yes. You can add pain after entry is saved. STEPS: Go to list page. Look for saved entry you want to edit. Note the date+time of entry. Tap (display) the entry. Tap low-right Copy/Edit icon. Tap-Yes. Tap-OK. Tap-Add Pain. Add extra pain type you want. Tap "Calendar" icon upper-right. Restore original date+time. Tap "Done". Check "Done."  Thanks.

content: Fantastic app! My doctors find it very, very helpful and it's very easy to add entries on the fly. My only suggestion is to make the playback feature switch automatically between front and back views. It's confusing to the doctor when an entry appears blank because it's on the other side. Kudos to the developers though. They did a fantastic job with this one.
replyContent: Thank you for your kind feedback ‚Äî it was much appreciated.  Your suggestion about seeing both image sides during the playback feature is very good and duly noted.  We have some ideas how to accomplish this for early next year. Thanks!   Email any questions: administration@nanolume.com

content: As someone who has been suffering from Chronic pain for over a decade, I find this app to be extremely useful for documenting my pain (including the type, location, and intensity) so I can share it with the doctors at the pain clinic. my only suggestion to improve the app would be to replace the front and back of the body with a 3D body that could be rotated.
replyContent: Thank you for your thoughtful comments.  We appreciate your suggestion and will consider it for future development. Please let us know if you have any questions about the app‚Äôs current functionality: administration@nanolume.com.

content: Extremely helpful tool to relay information to others even if they don't believe you atleast you can show you have a record and you're not crazy. Just think it should be cheaper for what it offers.
Awesome!
replyContent: Thank you for your comments on our exportable data options.  We have two different icons to initiate data-sharing:  (1) one is located on the top-left of the ‚ÄúEntries|Charts‚Äù screen to export a CSV file of saved numeric data; (2) one is on top-right of the ‚ÄúInteractive Summary & Animation‚Äù screen to export a PDF of saved drawings and notes.

content: I was looking for an app that would also track my meds. It seems that I overlooked that feature. I will try it again. Thanks for responding to my email.
replyContent: Yes, users can track their meds within our ‚ÄúNotes‚Äù feature.  When you record a medication change (along with any comments), a ‚Äúnotes icon‚Äù will appear on the entry line after the date-time of the relevant pain entry.  Let us know if you need any further information: administration@nanolume.com. Thanks.

content: I am a current patient and am having to translate myself from the McGill pain scale, back to pain 1-10. I find this program much different than Journaling. Thank you for creating this for all us in chronic pain. I believe this will prove very informative about the individual. An absolutely brilliant idea put into play.

This app is a must have tool for anyone who lives with chronic pain. It is very intuitive and user friendly. Using this tool regularly gives you the voice and language, through pictures and words, for what you've been trying to express. It speaks in a way that both medical professionals and families/friends understand. If you are a chronic pain warrior - you will never be without this amazing and powerful app!!
alot of options and easy to use to track pain

This app VERY EASY to use. And at ANY time I want I can use it to accurately describe current pain and location. It then allows me to write a note relating activity level or current flare. Then as a patient I can show this to my Dr who can get a quick and accurate presentation of daily life with chronic pain. EVERY PATIENT WITH CHRONIC PAIN SHOULD HAVE THIS APP.

This app is good for visualizing your pain types and areas, but does nothing else. I need to be able to chart medication ans procedures and aee how the pain responds. furthermore, you cant delete an entry if you messed up, so i have random entries with 0 pain. wish i could get a refund - this is useless for my needs and i bought it when i saw in another comment rhat you could track how your pain respond to treatment. maybe you can do that offline by comparing to your calendar, but not in this app
replyContent: Hello K.  Yes.  You can delete mistakes.  Please take a look at the user comment dated March 13, 2019.  If you wish, you can chart your meds and procedures for each entry you make by using the ‚Äúnotes‚Äù feature offered within the app.  Please contact us if you need assistance.  Thanks.  Support@nanolume.com.

content: just wish you could setup a notification every day to remind oneself to write up an entry.
replyContent: Your suggestion is a good one! We are right now finishing up a new feature that will allow users to email a PDF copy of all the pain maps and notes stored within the app. Once the above feature is released we will take a look at creating the daily notification alarm you mentioned. Pls email us if you have any questions: administration@nanolume.com.

content: Very user friendly, a great app to log various types of pain at all locations and keep track of pain levels over time.
replyContent: Thank you for your review!  We very much appreciated your comments.

content: I like the choices for pain tyoes and the ability to draw pain areas. Would like some improvements. I wish i could print out the pictures and any notes i made and not just a csv file for my doctor. Also it would be helpful to be able to include pain meds.
replyContent: Hello Anne.  We added a "share PDF" feature to our app shortly after you brought your request to our attention.  Hopefully you no longer have a need for a pain app, but if you do, could you contact us at: support@nanolume.com?  Our new PDF feature creates a downloadable copy of your charts, pictures, and notes.  Thanks.

content: *Edited: Exceptionally easy to use. I have multiple pain causing health issues, including fibromyalgia, arthritis, and endometriosis. This app allows you to detail the exact type of pain (extremely specific & descriptive). It even allows you to create your own pain description. It's very easy to mark the location of the pain. Customer service is beyond fabulous! Maker knew I had fibromyalgia and sent me a new study linking low B12 and other info to fibro. I only wish my doctors cared so much!
replyContent: Can you please clarify what you would like to see?  Our app can allow you to draw the exact pain intensity you want for each unique type of pain you want at any location you want.  Please contact us and I‚Äôll be happy to take a look at your needs.  I do think we can help you get precisely what you are looking for:  administration@nanolume.com.

content: it's been handy, but I wish you could download a file with all of the pictures too.
replyContent: Hello Kat. We added a "share PDF file" feature very shortly after you brought your wish to our attention. Hopefully you have no further need for a pain app, but if you do could you contact us? We have since improved upon your original wish ‚Äî you can now share or download a PDF copy of your charts, pictures, and notes.  Email: support@nanolume.com.

content: Can't seem to delete pain entries once you've entered them. so if you make a big mistake you can't get it out of your chart. Fixed. Thank you!
replyContent: (1) Go to the ‚ÄúEntries|Charts‚Äù page.  (2) Press and hold the pain-entry you want to delete until the entry-line turns ‚Äúblue‚Äù. (3) A trash can will appear on the upper-right side of the screen.  (4) Press the trash can and then agree to delete the unwanted entry.  Please contact us at ‚Äúadministration@nanolume.com‚Äù if there are any questions.

content: Latest update appeared to have erased the pain locale images, but the developer responded quickly to my concern. So thumbs up for support. This feature of the app is it's most valuable as a picture tells a thousand words. It's the best implementation of this feature in pain diaries that I've used so far.
replyContent: Very happy restarting your Samsung S7 phone restored what appeared to be a disappearance of the pain locale images after downloading our latest update. A phone restart is needed for Samsung phones that offer multiple resolutions. Relaunching the phone‚Äôs operating system enables the app to understand which of 3 screen resolutions to draw with.

content: This app has been very helpful with tracking my pain levels day to day, and will hopefully help me to get a diagnosis. The only issue I'm seeing is that copying a pain entry to a new day slides the pain areas over to the right just slightly. If that gets fixed, I will have no other issues with this app.
replyContent: Thank you for sending us screenshots of the glitch you were seeing with copied images. The screenshots and mobile device details you sent helped us isolate the problem. We released a new version of our app to fix this glitch. You‚Äôll need to restart your phone after downloading this update to enable the app to launch properly.

content: I really recommend this app to anyone in chronic pain. Easy to use, and gets very detailed. I love that we can add our own types of pain the app doesn't start with. for those that have many types of pain, this is a great way to show your doctor(s) exactly what is going on and where.
replyContent: Thank you for your comments!

content: What I am looking for in a pain tracking app is an app that can track my pain and the pain relief meds and how effective they are.
replyContent: Which of your above listed items are you saying that the app does not accomplish? The app does track pain in many dimensions and, also, does tracks how pain changes following any type of treatment. In order to correlate treatments-tried to treatment-responses we provide a ‚ÄúNotes‚Äù section. Please contact us for more info at support@nanolume.com. TY.

content: I have long searched for the perfect pain record app. I have tried more apps than I can remember but then I found Nanolume- a total godsend. This app is perfect and I would recommend anyone considering this app to buy it. It is so worth it. I can't praise it enough!
replyContent: Thank you for your comments and for reaching out to us.  Let us know if you or anyone else has any further questions:  administration@nanolume.com.

content: The app was easy to install and very intuitive to use. I like how this app allows me to track and locate each type of pain individually as well as collectively showing all pain types and body locations. It tracks intensity and the percentage of body surface affected. This too will help my doctor track my treatment progress. Thank you!
Great app for recording location of pain, but I can't seem to record a duration? It would be great to say that a certain pain has been there for hours etc.
replyContent: That‚Äôs a great idea we approached this way:  Each diary entry captures a ‚Äúmoment‚Äù in time displayed in ‚ÄúCharts‚Äù using an x-y plot to show the duration of pain‚Äîthe more entries made, the more accurate the plot.  If you forget a point you can use the Copy/Edit & Calendar features to create a missing point.  A user can also make a comment in ‚ÄúNotes.‚Äù

content:
This needs to be an app that all specialist give you to use. What a 
fantastic app. So easy to use and so many layer selections to pick from. 
You can add a layer of your own as well which is great. 10/10 for this app. 
Well worth the money. Only 1 thing that would make this better and that's 
the ability to zoom in.
replyContent: As of 1-OCT-18, our latest app update now offers "Zoom". Using 1 finger, double-tap over the area you wish to zoom-in to (magnify). Using 2 fingers, drag the magnified image to center the body area of interest.  Using 1 finger, draw a loop around the painful area. Using 1 finger, double-tap the screen (as needed) to return the image to normal.

content:
I do like the premise of this app. I have to keep a pain diary for the 
Doctor who administered cortisone into my foot. This is much easier than 
writing it down. Particularly as I'm not very mobile currently, it's saving 
me from hunting down pen and paper. However, there is one very big flaw. 
Hence why 3 stars and not 5. I cannot zoom into a limb to draw the pained 
area accurately. I'd suggest that at the next update, the development team 
look at hands, feet and head having an additional and separate page each or 
at the very least, allow for a zoom facility. It's near impossible to draw 
a pain area that consists of one toe and a bit of surrounding tissue, yet 
such data would be very valuable for the physician.
replyContent: Hello Wayne. We added the "zoom" feature you suggested shortly after you brought this need to our attention.  Hopefully you have no further need for any pain app, but if you do would it be possible to contact us?  Email: support@nanolume.com.

content:
I love that it calculates and keeps track of every entry submitted. It's 
easy to use and you can do each individual pain and then all layers. This 
is most helpful to all patients with CRPS. They can do screen shots etc and 
email to their physician.
